title: What to Do When Your Car Breaks Down in Tulsa, Oklahoma
description: Car trouble can strike at the worst times—on your way to work, running errands, or heading home after a long day. If your vehicle breaks down anywhere in Tulsa, don’t panic. Here’s a simple, step-by-step guide to keep...
content:
Car trouble can strike at the worst times—on your way to work, running errands, or heading home after a long day. If your vehicle breaks down anywhere in Tulsa, don’t panic. Here’s a simple, step-by-step guide to keep you safe and get back on the road quickly.

1. Get to Safety First

If your car is still rolling, carefully steer it to the side of the road. Use your turn signal and avoid sudden movements. Aim for a safe spot away from traffic, like a shoulder or a lot. If you're near downtown, Guthrie Green or Cherry Street can be decent landmarks to help explain your location to help services.

2. Turn On Your Hazard Lights

Hazard lights let other drivers know you're in trouble. Turn them on right away to avoid collisions and make your vehicle more visible, especially at night or in low visibility conditions.

3. Stay in Your Vehicle (If Safe)

If you're on a busy roadway like Highway 169 or the Broken Arrow Expressway, it's safest to stay inside your vehicle with your seatbelt fastened. Only exit if you're in a safe, low-traffic area.

4. Call a Local Towing Service

This is where Miklos Towing comes in. We’re a locally trusted name offering 24/7 emergency towing in Tulsa. Whether you're stuck in Brookside or near the Blue Dome District, we’ve got fast, friendly drivers ready to help.

Call Miklos Towing at (918) 555-1234 – we’re always on standby.

5. Know What to Say When You Call

When calling a tow company, have this info ready:

  • Your exact location or nearest landmark
  • Make and model of your vehicle
  • Problem you're experiencing (e.g. engine failure, flat tire)
  • Whether you're in a safe area

6. Don’t Accept Help from Strangers

Kindness is appreciated, but unsolicited help—especially at night—can be risky. Politely decline and let a professional service like Miklos handle it.

7. Wait in a Visible, Safe Area

If you exit the car, stay where other drivers can see you, preferably behind a guardrail or away from the road’s edge. Avoid walking along highways.

Bonus: Prepare for Next Time

Here are a few items to keep in your car for emergencies:

  • Phone charger or battery bank
  • Reflective triangle or road flares
  • Blanket or poncho (especially in Tulsa's unpredictable weather)
  • Printed card with your towing provider’s info
